Welcome to Eigenvalue Extraction Algorithms’s documentation!¶

Hessenberg¶

src.hessenberg.hessenberg_transform(M, calc_u=True)¶

Converts a given complex square matrix to Hessenberg form using Householder transformations. Produces the matrices H and U such that \(M = UHU^{*}\), where \(H\) is in hessenberg form and \(U\) is a unitary matrix.

Parameters

  • M (ndarray) – A complex square matrix.

  • calc_u (bool) – Flag to determine whether to calculate the transfomation matrix.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • H

  • U

src.hessenberg.householder_reflector(x)¶

Produces the Householder vector based on the input vector x. The householder vector \(u\) acts as

\[\begin{split}(I-2uu^{*})x = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \alpha \\ 0 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \\ \end{array} \right]\end{split}\]
Parameters

x (array) – A complex numpy array who’s entries after the 1st element need to be 0ed.

Returns

The Householder vector.

Return type

numpy array

QR Decomposition¶

class src.qr.QR(M)¶

A simple implementation of the QR algorithm and its variations.

double_shift(eps, n_iter)¶

Performs an inefficient double shift for a real valued hessenberg matrix H with complex eigenvalues. Calculates the real matrix \(M = H^2 - 2\Re(\sigma)H + |\sigma|^2 I\) and the double shifted \(H_2 = Q^{T} H Q\), where \(Q\) is from the \(QR\) decomposition of \(M\). Produces the real schur form \(H = U^{*}RU\).

Parameters

n_iter (int) – Number of double iterations to perform.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • \(U\)

  • \(R\)

Raises

ValueError: – If self.H is not real.

static extract_eigs(M)¶

Extracts the eigenvalues from the matrix M which is the (quasi) upper triangular matrix received from any functions that produce the Schur decomposition.

Parameters

M (ndarray) – A quasi upper triangular square matrix.

Return type

R

francis_double_step(eps, n_iter)¶

Performs an efficient version of the double shift algorithm to avoid complex airthmetic. Produces the Schur decomposition of \(H = URU^{*}\). Utilises the Implicit Q-Theorem to handle efficient computation of the real matrix \(M = H^2 - 2\Re(\sigma)H + |\sigma|^2 I\).

Parameters

  • eps (float) – Tolerance to break matrix self.H.

  • n_iter (int) – Number of iterations to perform.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • \(U\)

  • \(R\)

static givens_22(x)¶

Generates an \(2 \times 2\) special Givens Rotation matrix based on the on the \(2 \times 1\) vector x. Function is useful for producing Givens matrices stabily and efficiently. For a Givens rotation matrix \(G\), vector \(u\).

\[\begin{split}G u = \left[ \begin{array}{c} u_1 \\ 0 \\ \end{array} \right]\end{split}\]
Parameters

x (array) – \(2 \times 2\) vector who’s 2nd entry needs to be reduced to 0.

Return type

A \(2 \times 2\) Givens rotation matrix.

static givens_rotation(i, j, x, n)¶

Generates an n \(\times\) n special Givens Rotation matrix based on the parameters i, j, x, and n. The rotation matrix acts to reduce the j th component of the vector x to 0. For a Givens rotation matrix \(G\), vector \(u\) and index \(j\)

\[\begin{split}G u = \left[ \begin{array}{c} u_1 \\ \vdots \\ u_{j - 1} \\ 0 \\ u_{j - 1} \\ \vdots \\ u_{n} \\ \end{array} \right]\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • i (int) – ith row.

  • j (int) – jth column.

  • x (array) – Vector who’s jth entry needs to be reduced to 0.

  • n (int) – Size of the returned Givens Matrix.

Return type

A Givens rotation matrix.

qr_hessenberg(M)¶

Performs one step of the \(QR\) algorithm using a hessenberg matrix H. Procedurally generates the \(QR\) decomposition of H exploiting the fact that H is in hessenberg form.

Parameters

M (ndarray) – An n \(\times\) n hessenberg matrix.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • \(Q\)

  • \(RQ\)

qr_rayleigh_shift(eps, n_iter)¶

Performs the \(QR\) algorithm employing the hessenberg method for the decomposition and utilises the Rayleigh shift with deflation. Produces the Schur decomposition of \(H = URU^{*}\).

Parameters

  • eps (float) – Tolerance to break matrix self.H.

  • n_iter (int) – Number of iterations to perform.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • \(U\)

  • \(R\)

qr_wilkinson_shift(eps, n_iter)¶

Performs the QR algorithm employing the hessenberg method for the decomposition and utilises the Wilkinson shift. Produces the Schur decomposition of \(H = U^{*}RU\).

Parameters

  • eps (float) – Tolerance to break matrix self.H.

  • n_iter (int) – Number of iterations to perform.

Return type

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns

  • \(U\)

  • \(R\)

static wilkinson_shift(M)¶

A function to compute a stable numerical value of the Wilkison shift (\(\mu\)). For a matrix in \(\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\)

\[\begin{split}\left[ \begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \\ \end{array} \right],\end{split}\]
\[\mu = d - \frac{b^2\,\text{sign}(\sigma)}{|\sigma| + \sqrt{\sigma^2 + b^2}}\]

where

\[\sigma = \frac{1}{2}\left(a - d\right).\]
Parameters

M (ndarray) – A \(2 \times 2\) matrix from which the shift is computed.

Return type

\(\mu\)

Raises

ValueError: – If M.shape[0] != 2 or M.shape[1] != 2.

Utility¶

src.utility.closeness(actual, desired, tol, get_mismatch=True)¶

Judges if arrays are close to each other upto a certain tol using the equation. If there are mismatched values, then a dataframe containg those values and their differences is returned for analysis.

For arrays \(x\) and \(y\), the function checks

\(|a - b| \leq tol\) for each positional pair \(a \in x\) and \(b \in y\).

Parameters

  • actual (Iterable) – The array with predicitons.

  • desired (Iterable) – The array with desired values.

  • tol (float) – The error tolerance.

  • get_mismatch (bool) – Whether to return the mismatched elements, if any.

Return type

Tuple[bool, Optional[DataFrame]]

Returns

  • Boolean value indicating if all elements of both arrays are close.

  • Mismatched elements, if any.

Raises

ValueError: – If actual and desired array lengths are not equal.

src.utility.complex_matrix(n, a, b, type_=<class 'numpy.complex256'>)¶

Produces a random n \(\times\) n complex square matrix. The absolute real and complex parts of allof all values in the matrix range between 2a and 2b.

Parameters

  • n (int) – Square matrix size.

  • a (float) – Lower limit for random number generator.

  • b (float) – Upper limit for random number generator.

  • type_ (dtype) – Complex numpy type.

Return type

A complex square matrix.

Raises

ValueError – If b \(\leq\) a.

src.utility.eig22(M)¶

Computes the eigenvalues of the \(2 \times 2\) matrix M.

Parameters

M (ndarray) – A \(2 \times 2\) complex matrix.

Return type

Tuple[Union[complex, float], Union[complex, float]]

Returns

  • First eigenvalue.

  • Second eigenvalue.

Raises

ValueError: – If M is not square and of shape \(2 \times 2\).

src.utility.sign(z)¶

A general sign function for complex valued inputs.

Parameters

z (Union[complex, float]) – A complex number.

Return type

1 if z = 0 otherwise z / |z|.
